Expectation1: Meet sales targets set by management
Situation1: Midway through the week, their individual sales numbers are already on pace to surpass the quota.
Situation2: They casually mention a religious story during a community gathering.
Story: I sat at my desk, headset pressing into my ear, the hum of the call center around me. My sales numbers blinked on the screen—already ahead of target, my manager’s praise still echoing from this morning. “Keep it up, push for more,” he’d said. The pressure to keep climbing, to not let up, was a constant thrum in my chest. Later, at the community center, I slipped into my other role. As a pastor, I shared a story from scripture, hoping to inspire kindness and honesty. The group listened, nodding, some faces softening with understanding. But as I spoke, my mind flickered back to the calls I’d made—how I’d nudged hesitant voices toward a sale, glossed over details to close the deal. The expectation to teach truth and compassion clashed with the tactics I used to meet quotas. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in, the demands of my job and my calling pulling me in opposite directions. My heart pounded as I wondered which voice I should listen to.
